sections.title: Jonathan Renews Alliances with Rome and Sparta
The Capture of Jonathan and Israel’s Distress

verses.text: When Jonathan realized that the situation was in his favor, he selected some men and sent them to Rome to reaffirm and renew their friendship.
verses.comment: Jonathan seeks to strengthen alliances at a politically advantageous moment. Reference to past Jewish-Roman relations.
verses.sectionHeader: Jonathan Renews Alliances with Rome and Sparta

verses.text: He also sent letters with similar purpose to the Spartans and to other regions.
verses.comment: This underscores the broad diplomatic efforts; Sparta was believed to have ancestral ties to the Jews.

verses.text: When his envoys arrived in Rome and entered the senate, they declared, 'High priest Jonathan and the Jewish nation have sent us to renew the friendship and alliance previously made with you.'
verses.comment: The formal introduction hints at previous agreements between Jews and Romans.

verses.text: The Romans wrote letters to the people in every territory, asking them to allow the envoys safe passage as they traveled to Judah.
verses.comment: Roman support by granting safe conduct shows the strength of the alliance.

verses.text: Here is a copy of the letter Jonathan sent to the Spartans:
verses.comment: The narrative now directly quotes the letter to the Spartans, reflecting historic Jewish-Spartan correspondence.

verses.text: "Jonathan the high priest, the council of elders, the priests, and the rest of the Jewish people send greetings to their brothers in Sparta.
verses.comment: The letter is styled in classic greetings format, expressing kinship.

verses.text: Long ago, Arius, your king, sent a letter to High Priest Onias, stating that we are brothers, as the enclosed copy shows.
verses.comment: Claims of ancient ties between Jews and Spartans were popular in the Hellenistic period, possibly legendary.

verses.text: Onias accepted the envoy with honor and received the letter, which clearly affirmed friendship and alliance.
verses.comment: Hospitality and formal receiving of envoys was a sign of respect in ancient diplomacy.

verses.text: Although we do not require these assurances, since we have our sacred books to encourage us,
verses.comment: The sacred texts give the Jews confidence apart from human alliances.

verses.text: we have decided to send this message to renew our family ties and friendship, so that we may not become strangers to each other, especially since a long time has passed since your last communication.
verses.comment: Diplomatic exchanges helped preserve alliances over time.

verses.text: We remember you on every occasion, especially at our festivals and appropriate times, during sacrifices and prayers, as it is proper to remember our brothers.
verses.comment: Praying for allies during public worship reflects their importance.

verses.text: And we rejoice in the good things that have happened to you.
verses.comment: Expressing joy at a fellow nation's prosperity is a typical diplomatic courtesy.

verses.text: As for us, we have faced many dangers and wars, surrounded by enemy kings who have attacked us.
verses.comment: Reference to persistent struggles faced by the Jewish nation.

verses.text: We chose not to burden you or our other allies and friends with requests for help in these wars,
verses.comment: Highlights Jewish self-reliance and respect for ally relations.

verses.text: because our help comes from heaven, and with Heaven’s support we have been rescued from our enemies and they were humbled.
verses.comment: Emphasizes divine aid as the true deliverer in Jewish theology.

verses.text: Thus, we have chosen Numenius son of Antiochus, and Antipater son of Jason, and sent them to Rome to renew our earlier alliance and friendship.
verses.comment: Sending trusted representatives reflects the seriousness of renewing alliances.

verses.text: We instructed them to visit you as well, to deliver our greetings, and to give you this letter about renewing our kinship.
verses.comment: Envoys served multiple diplomatic channels during missions.

verses.text: So now, please send us a reply."
verses.comment: Conventional conclusion to ancient diplomatic letters, inviting response.

verses.text: Here is a copy of the letter sent to Onias:
verses.comment: The following is the ancient letter from the Spartans.

verses.text: "King Arius of the Spartans to Onias the high priest, greetings.
verses.comment: Beginning of Arius' diplomatic greeting.

verses.text: It has been discovered in records that the Spartans and Jews are brothers, both descended from Abraham.
verses.comment: The claim of common ancestry is possibly legendary, aiming to solidify relations.

verses.text: Now that this is known, please write us about your condition and welfare.
verses.comment: Request for a report on Jewish affairs, a diplomatic courtesy.

verses.text: As for us, we assure you that your cattle and possessions are ours, and ours are yours. We have instructed our representatives to relay this message to you."
verses.comment: Demonstrates deep diplomatic goodwill and a sense of shared property.

verses.text: Jonathan learned that officials of Demetrius had returned with a larger force than before to fight against him.
verses.comment: The political-military threat from Demetrius re-emerges.

verses.text: So Jonathan left Jerusalem, marched against them in the region of Hamath, not giving them a chance to enter his land.
verses.comment: A preemptive strike to protect Judea from invasion.

verses.text: Jonathan sent spies to their camp, and they brought back word that the enemy was preparing to attack the Jews by night.
verses.comment: Espionage and intelligence were common in ancient warfare.

verses.text: As the sun set, Jonathan instructed his men to stay alert, keep their weapons ready, and stand guard all night for battle; he also posted sentries around the camp.
verses.comment: Jonathan demonstrates careful military preparedness.

verses.text: When the enemy learned that Jonathan and his men were ready to fight, they panicked; so they lit fires in camp and withdrew.
verses.comment: The enemy loses morale and flees, using diversionary fires.

verses.text: Jonathan and his men did not realize this until morning, when they saw the burning campfires.
verses.comment: Nocturnal movements often caused confusion in ancient battles.

verses.text: Jonathan pursued them, but could not overtake them, as they had already crossed the Eleutherus river.
verses.comment: The Eleutherus River marked an important boundary in northern Syria.

verses.text: So Jonathan turned toward the Arabs called Zabadeans, attacked and defeated them, and took their goods as spoil.
verses.comment: Hostile Arab tribes are mentioned as opponents on occasion in the Maccabean narratives.

verses.text: After this, he broke camp and went to Damascus, passing through that whole area.
verses.comment: Damascus was a significant urban center in Syria.

verses.text: Meanwhile, Simon traveled as far as Askalon and nearby strongholds. He turned toward Joppa and captured it by surprise.
verses.comment: Simon is highlighted for his own military campaigns in the region.

verses.text: He had heard that Joppa was going to be handed over to the supporters of Demetrius, so he stationed a garrison there to secure it.
verses.comment: Controlling strategic coastal cities was vital for military and trade.

verses.text: After Jonathan returned, he met with the elders to discuss building strongholds in Judea.
verses.comment: Defensive construction projects were frequently used to consolidate control.

verses.text: They planned to further fortify the walls of Jerusalem and build a high wall to separate the citadel from the city, cutting it off so that those inside could neither buy nor sell.
verses.comment: The citadel (Acra) in Jerusalem was a Hellenistic garrison threatening Jewish autonomy.

verses.text: So they gathered and rebuilt the city; a section of the wall in the eastern valley had collapsed, and Jonathan fixed the part called Chaphenatha.
verses.comment: Chaphenatha is likely a specific part of Jerusalem’s fortifications.

verses.text: Simon also built up the fortress Adida in the Shephelah, strengthened it with walls and added barred gates.
verses.comment: The Shephelah is the lowland district west of Jerusalem, key for defense.

verses.text: Then Trypho began plotting to seize the throne in Asia. He put on the royal crown and set his sights against King Antiochus.
verses.comment: Trypho’s ambition presents another political threat.

verses.text: Fearing that Jonathan would oppose him or wage war, Trypho continuously schemed to capture and kill him, so he came to Beth-shan.
verses.comment: Beth-shan (Scythopolis) is strategically located at the junction of trade and military routes.

verses.text: Jonathan gathered forty thousand elite soldiers and went to meet him at Beth-shan.
verses.comment: A large army is mustered to respond to the threat.

verses.text: When Trypho saw the size of Jonathan's force, he was afraid to attack and did not raise his hand against him.
verses.comment: Trypho’s fear leads him to refrain from open confrontation.

verses.text: Instead, he welcomed Jonathan with honors, introduced him to all his trusted officials, gave him gifts, and instructed both his friends and soldiers to treat Jonathan as they would himself.
verses.comment: Trypho feigns friendship while plotting treachery.

verses.text: He then said to Jonathan, 'Why have you troubled these people when there is no war between us?
verses.comment: Trypho uses cunning words to lower Jonathan's guard.

verses.text: Send your troops home now. Keep only a few men with you, and come with me to Ptolemais. I will hand over the city and all the other strongholds, the remaining troops, and all officials to you. Then I'll return home—this is the reason I came.'
verses.comment: Trypho attempts to separate Jonathan from the main force for betrayal.

verses.text: Jonathan trusted him, did as he suggested, and sent his army back to Judea.
verses.comment: This act of trust sets up Jonathan for Trypho’s betrayal.

verses.text: He kept only three thousand men with him, two thousand stationed in Galilee, and one thousand who went with him.
verses.comment: Reduces his protective force, increasing his vulnerability.

verses.text: When Jonathan entered Ptolemais, the residents closed the gates, captured him, and killed everyone who had entered with him.
verses.comment: Trypho’s treachery is realized, leading to Jonathan’s capture.

verses.text: Trypho then sent infantry and cavalry into Galilee and the Great Plain to destroy Jonathan's remaining soldiers.
verses.comment: Trypho seeks to annihilate all remaining Jewish resistance.

verses.text: But once the troops realized Jonathan had been captured and his men killed, they rallied together, forming a close defensive line, determined to fight.
verses.comment: The remaining soldiers refuse to give up, showing unity even in crisis.

verses.text: When their pursuers saw they would resist to the end, they turned back.
verses.comment: The resolve of Jonathan's soldiers saves them from annihilation.

verses.text: So the troops made it safely back to Judea, mourning Jonathan and his companions. They were filled with fear, and all Israel deeply lamented.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s loss represents a national tragedy, evoking mass mourning.
verses.sectionHeader: The Capture of Jonathan and Israel’s Distress

verses.text: Seeing this, the neighboring nations plotted to destroy Israel, saying, 'They have no leader or helper now; let's attack them and wipe out their memory from among all people.'
verses.comment: Israel is threatened by its enemies in the absence of a strong leader, a recurring theme in Jewish history.
